courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy
courses.description: This course offers a general and fun introduction to philosophical thinking and problems. Students will gain a basic familiarity with some of the major philosophical fields, figures, and issues from the perspective of a variety of global philosophical traditions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Grasp basic concepts in philosophical thinking.

2. Ability to reflect in a critical manner on philosophical issues and their relations.

3. Understand the importance of philosophical reflection and bring it to bear on things that matter in life.

4. Become familiar with some of the important historical figures, traditions, and sub-fields in the discipline of philosophy
courses.course_syllabus:
Through philosophical discussion, students are encouraged to develop their own views and to defend them with critical reasoning. Topics to be discussed may include: the concept and method of philosophy, theories of world, knowledge, self, logic, value, beauty, and political thought.

藉著哲學討論，學生當可利用批判思考，建立並辯解個人觀點。本科的題目可涉及: 「哲學」的意思、哲學的方法、有關世界的理論、知識、自我、邏輯、價值、美，以及政治思想。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophical Thinking Through Writing
courses.description: This is a writing-intensive introductory course aimed at training students in the basic skills needed for philosophical reading, thinking, and writing. The course introduces principles of philosophical argumentation and critical thinking, along with techniques for philosophical writing. The instructor and students then jointly employ these principles and techniques to analyze and discuss selected philosophical problems. Students will be required to apply the methods of argument and writing skills introduced in the course to compose several short argumentative essays.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate competence in reading comprehension, critical evaluation, and argumentative writing with respect to at least three philosophical topics.

2. Demonstrate competence in writing a short philosophy essay that explains a problem and then states and defends a thesis concerning it.
courses.course_syllabus:
This is a writing-intensive introductory course aimed at training students in the basic skills needed for philosophical reading, thinking, and writing. The course introduces principles of philosophical argumentation and critical thinking, along with techniques for philosophical writing. The instructor and students then jointly employ these principles and techniques to analyze and discuss selected philosophical problems. Students will be required to apply the methods of argument and writing skills introduced in the course to compose several short argumentative essays.

本科旨在培養學生的哲學閱讀、寫作與思考能力，一方面介紹哲學論證與批判思考的基本原則，並具體說明撰寫哲學論文的方法，另一方面，講師及同學將共同把堂上介紹的原則及方法，用以分析及討論哲學問題。同時，同學必須應用堂上介紹的論證方法與寫作技巧撰寫哲學短文。

Course questionnaire

Teacher’s reflections
courses.required_readings: To be specified by teacher from within the respective list of recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings: The reading will include one or two general introductions to philosophy and from two to six scholarly articles on each of the philosophical topics treated in the course.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Logic
courses.description: This course is designed to develop students’ ability to analyze and critically evaluate arguments from a logical point of view. It will provide them with a basic understanding of such concepts as reasons, implication, validity, and fallacies. Students will learn the logical principles of deductive and inductive inferences and the techniques of applying them for determining the validity of arguments. Elements of good reasoning from an informal perspective will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED1111 or 1112
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire logical skills and critical disposition.

2. Grasp of basic concepts and methods in logic.

3. Translate arguments in ordinary language into symbolic argument forms.

4. Recognize common valid argument forms.

5. Ability to identify, classify, and assess arguments in various contexts.

6. Ability to identify and analyze informal fallacies.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed to develop students’ ability to analyze and critically evaluate arguments from a logical point of view. It will provide them with a basic understanding of such concepts as reasons, implication, validity, and fallacies. Students will learn the logical principles of deductive and inductive inferences and the techniques of applying them for determining the validity of arguments. Elements of good reasoning from an informal perspective will also be covered.

本科提供基本的邏輯學訓練，培養學生的邏輯思辨以及評鑑論證的能力。著重闡釋邏輯學的基本概念 ─ 理由、蘊涵、對確、謬誤等，以及演繹和歸納推論的邏輯法則和應用方法，又涉及非形式邏輯的推理原則。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophies of Life
courses.description: This course aims to help students understand important theories and ideas in philosophies of life, and learn how to use these ideas and theories in thinking and analyzing contemporary social, ethical and political problems in our everyday life.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be familiar with the main ideas and theories in philosophy of life.

2. Understand the contemporary practical issues in our life.

3. In their papers, students should demonstrate the/an ability to analyze life issues and defend their own views.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course aims to help students understand important theories and ideas in philosophies of life, and learn how to use these ideas and theories in thinking and analyzing contemporary social, ethical and political problems in our everyday life.

本科旨在引導學生理解人生哲學基本問題、概念與原理，並學習如何運用這些概念原理對我們當前面臨的社會、人生、道德問題進行哲學性的分析和思考。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: History of Chinese Philosophy I
courses.description:
The course introduces the history of Chinese philosophy from the Pre-Qin period to the Two Han dynasties (from the 8th century BCE to the 3rd century CE). Topics include: Pre-Qin Confucianism, Pre-Qin Daoism, the Mohist school, the Legalist school, the Two Hans Confucianism.

Advisory to Majors (4-year curriculum): to be taken in year 2.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate familiarity with the major ideas and theories of the philosophers and the philosophical schools covered in the course.

2. Acquire skills in textual study, philosophical thinking and writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course introduces the history of Chinese philosophy from the Pre-Qin period to the Two Han dynasties (from the 8th century BCE to the 3rd century CE). Topics include: Pre-Qin Confucianism, Pre-Qin Daoism, the Mohist school, the Legalist school, the Two Hans Confucianism.

墨家、法家、兩漢儒學等。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: History of Western Philosophy I
courses.description:
The course introduces students to the history of ancient and medieval Western philosophy. Topics include: Presocratic Greek philosophy, classical Greek philosophy and Hellenistic thoughts; Medieval Patristics and Scholasticism.

Advisory to Majors (4-year curriculum): to be taken in year 2.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will be expected to demonstrate familiarity with the major ideas and theories of the philosophers, as well as the relations between the various philosophical movements, covered in the course.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course introduces students to the history of ancient and medieval Western philosophy. Topics include: Presocratic Greek philosophy, classical Greek philosophy and Hellenistic thoughts; Medieval Patristics and Scholasticism.

本科介紹西方古代至中古期的哲學史，內容包括：先蘇格拉底時期的希臘哲學，希臘古典哲學；希臘化時期的哲學，中古教父哲學與經院哲學等。

courses.recommended_readings:
The course reading list will vary from semester to semester, but will generally include two or more introductions to the history of Western philosophy, and a selection from the works of the philosophers covered in the course. References may include:

1. John Burnet, Greek Philosophy : Thales to Plato. London: Macmillan, 1964.

2. Frederick C. Copleston, A History of Philosophy, 9 vols. (esp. vols. 1-3), New York: Image Books, 1993.

3. G. W. F. Hegel, Lectures on the history of philosophy: the lectures of 1825-1826, ed. R. F. Brown, trans. R.F. Brown and J.M. Stewart with the assistance of H.S. Harris, Berkeley: University of California Press, 1990.

4. Heinz Heimsoeth, Die sechs großen Themen der abendländischen Metaphysik. Darmstadt: Wissenschaftliche Buchgesellschaft, 1981. Now also in English: The Six Great Themes of Western Metaphysics and the End of the Middle Ages, Wayne State University Press, 1994.

5. Elmar Holenstein, Philosophie-Atlas: Orte und Wege des Denkens. Zürich: Ammann Verlag, 2004.

6. Julían Marías, History of Philosophy. transl. from the Spanish by Stanley Appelbaum and Clarence C. Strowbridge, New York: Dover, 1967.

7. Joachim Ritter und Karlfried Gründer (ed.), Historisches Wörterbuch der Philosophie. Basel: Schwabe, 1985ff.

8. Bertrand Russell, A History of Western Philosophy, London: Routledge, 1993.

9. Alfred Weber, History of Philosophy, tranl. By Frank Thilly, New York: Scribners & Sons, 1908.

10. Wilhelm Windelband, A History of Philosophy: With Special Reference to the Formation and Development of its Problems and Conceptions, trans. J. H. Tufts, New York: Macmillan Co., 1901.

11. 傳偉勳，《西洋哲學史》。台北：三民書局，1965。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: History of Western Philosophy II
courses.description:
The course introduces students to the history of modern Western philosophy. Topics include: philosophical backgrounds and movements leading to modern philosophy, the confrontation between rationalism and empiricism, Kant’s critical philosophy, Hegel’s idealism, and other 19th-century philosophical developments.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2.
courses.learning_outcomes: The course introduces students to the history of modern Western philosophy. Topics include: philosophical backgrounds and movements leading to modern philosophy, the confrontation between rationalism and empiricism, Kant’s critical philosophy, Hegel’s idealism, and other 19th-century philosophical developments.

本科介紹近代西方哲學史，內容包括：近代西方哲學的背景、理性主義與經驗主義、康德批判哲學、黑格爾觀念論，以及其他十九世紀哲學趨勢。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy and Human Conditions
courses.description:
This course is a small-class ‘problem-oriented’ seminar. It is designed for first-year major students to develop an ability to analyze and reflect on contemporary human conditions from a philosophical perspective. Main topics may include: life and death; the meaning of life; faiths and religions; human’s place in nature; self, freedom, and rights; technological revolution and human alienation; love and friendship.

Advisory: For Majors (4-year curriculum) only; to be taken in year 1.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Understand contemporary human conditions from a philosophical point of view.

2) Develop own critical views on the meanings and values of life.

3) Research further the issues taught.

4) Learn how to reason and argue cogently in group discussions and debates.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is a small-class ‘problem-oriented’ seminar. It is designed for first-year major students to develop an ability to analyze and reflect on contemporary human conditions from a philosophical perspective. Main topics may include: life and death; the meaning of life; faiths and religions; human’s place in nature; self, freedom, and rights; technological revolution and human alienation; love and friendship.

此乃一年級主修科，形式為「問題為本」之小班研討，旨在引導學生對人類的當今處境作哲學的分析和反思。課題可包括：生與死；人生的意義；信仰與宗教；人在自然界的位置；自我、自由與權利； 科技革命與人的異化；愛情與友情等。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Symbolic Logic
courses.description:
This is an intermediate-level course in formal logic, concentrating on standard first-order logic. The core of this course is the construction of formal systems for propositional logic and predicate logic. Four main styles of formal systems will be discussed:
1. Natural deduction,
2. Axiomatic proofs,
3. Semantic tableaux, and
4. Sequent calculi.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Grasp concepts and methods in intermediate-level logic.

2. Understand the philosophical significance of modern logic.

3. Ability to construct formal systems of propositional and predicate logic.

4. Ability to analyze and critically evaluate formal systems.

5. Understand the characteristics and value of the four main styles of formal systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
This is an intermediate-level course in formal logic, concentrating on standard first-order logic. The core of this course is the construction of formal systems for propositional logic and predicate logic. Four main styles of formal systems will be discussed:

1. Natural deduction,

2. Axiomatic proofs,

3. Semantic tableaux, and

4. Sequent calculi.

本科教授中等程度的形式邏輯學，集中討論標準一階邏輯。旨在說明如何構作命題邏輯與謂詞邏輯的形式系統，並針對四種主流的形式系統進行批判性的比較與分析：
1. 自然演繹法，

2. 公理法，

3. 真值樹法，以及

4. 序列演算法。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Introductory Latin
courses.description: This course provides a basic knowledge of Latin vocabulary and grammar with the intention to demonstrate the role played by Latin in medieval Western thoughts and modern Western culture. The course will also touch on the relation between Latin and Western philosophy, law, medicine and literature.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Manage the elementary Latin in order to be able to learn independently the language on the web.

2. Know the logic and complexity of the Latin language in comparison to Chinese and English.

3. Understand the cultural and historical background of the Latin-speaking Romans.

4. Understand the influence of Latin on the Western culture.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Ethics
courses.description:
This course is designed for students to learn how to think about fundamental ethical problems, and how to articulate their thoughts. It also introduces them to some key texts in moral philosophy and helps them to analyze and evaluate the arguments presented therein. Topics to be discussed may include the good life, conceptions of happiness, rationality and morality, duties to others, duties to self.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be familiar with some of the central issues in ethics, which might be issues in history of ethics or in contemporary ethics.

2. Be able to read analytically, such that they can identify distinct parts of an argument and grasp each part’s role in the overall structure.

3. Be able to read critically, such that they can raise your own questions and form their own objections to the material.

4. Be able to discuss arguments critically and constructively.

5. Be able to defend their own position by giving reasons and explaining the force of those reasons.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed for students to learn how to think about fundamental ethical problems, and how to articulate their thoughts. It also introduces them to some key texts in moral philosophy and helps them to analyze and evaluate the arguments presented therein. Topics to be discussed may include the good life, conceptions of happiness, rationality and morality, duties to others, duties to self.

本科旨在引導學生思考一些重要而基礎的倫理問題，並表達及闡明其看法。學生會研讀一些道德哲學的重要著作，嘗試分析和評價其中之論證。討論之課題可包括：美好之人生、關於幸福的種種觀點、理性與道德、對他人之責任、對自己之責任等等。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Pre-Qin Confucian Philosophy
courses.description:
The course studies the philosophical thoughts and their development of Pre-Qin Confucianism through intensive reading and interpretation of classical Confucian texts such as the Analects, Mencius, Xunzi.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Have a grasp of the major ideas and theories of Pre-Qin Confucian philosophy.

2. Read and interpret the texts covered in the course.

3. Reflect the modern relevance of Pre-Qin Confucian philosophy.

4. Be able to engage in critical discussion, to put forward and defend their own ideas concerning Confucian philosophy.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Topics in Medieval Western Philosophy
courses.description:
During the Middle Ages in the West, people lived under a certain unity and uniformity commanded by the strong influence of Christianity and the common acceptance of the importance of faith in daily life. This course aims at presenting the thoughts of these centuries developed in serenity and piety together with the breakthroughs made by individual thinkers, such as Boethius, John Scotus Erigena, Anselm of Canterbury, Peter Abelard, Bonaventura di Giovanni Fidanza, Albertus Magnus, Thomas Aquinas, Meister Eckhart, John Duns Scotus, and William of Ockham.
Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge of the selected topics of the course.

2. Have a solid grasp of the philosophical issues of the selected topics of the course.

3. Demonstrate familiarity with the primary/secondary source texts.

4. Be able to articulate and defend a philosophical thesis of their own.
courses.course_syllabus:
During the Middle Ages in the West, people lived under a certain unity and uniformity commanded by the strong influence of Christianity and the common acceptance of the importance of faith in daily life. This course aims at presenting the thoughts of these centuries developed in serenity and piety together with the breakthroughs made by individual thinkers, such as Boethius, John Scotus Erigena, Anselm of Canterbury, Peter Abelard, Bonaventura di Giovanni Fidanza, Albertus Magnus, Thomas Aquinas, Meister Eckhart, John Duns Scotus, and William of Ockham. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

西歐中世紀的人民備受基督信仰的影響，生活在特定的統合及劃一氣氛中，一般地公認信仰在日常生活中的重要性。
本科介紹在這些平和及虔誠氛圍渡過的世紀中，個別思想家作出的突破，例如波其武、愛留根納、安瑟倫、阿伯拉德、波拿文都拉、大阿伯都、多瑪斯、厄克哈特、鄧斯各脫、歐坎。學生最多可修讀教授不同課題的相同科目及取得相關學分兩次。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Indian Philosophy
courses.description:
This course is designed to provide a basic understanding of Indian philosophy. The contents include: the background of Indian philosophy; the Vedas and the Upaniṣads; Anti-Brahmanism: Materialism (Cārvāka), Jainism, Buddhism; the six systems derived from Brahmanism: Sāṅkhya, Yoga, Nyāya, Vaiśeṣika, Mīmāṃsā and Vedānta; contemporary Indian thought.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge regarding six orthodox and three unorthodox philosophical schools in ancient India.

2. Understand the central issues of Indian philosophy in three major areas, i.e., metaphysics, epistemology, and philosophy of religion.

3. Ability to work independently and critically on the primary and secondary sources in Indian philosophy.

4. Explore the relevant concepts and issues in their contemporary significance.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed to provide a basic understanding of Indian philosophy. The contents include: the background of Indian philosophy; the Vedas and the Upanisads; Anti-Brahmanism: Materialism (Lokayata), Jainism, Buddhism; the six systems derived from Brahmanism: Samkhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisesika, Mimamsa and Vedanta; contemporary Indian thought.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Indian Buddhist Philosophy
courses.description:
This course deals with the main philosophical issues in the various stages of Indian Buddhism. It is divided into five parts: Early Buddhism, Abhidharma, Madhyamaka, Vijñānavāda and Pramāṇavāda.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge of four major philosophical schools of Indian Buddhism.

2. Understand the central issues of Indian Buddhist philosophy in four major areas, i.e., metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and philosophy of religion.

3. Ability to work independently and critically on the primary and secondary sources in Indian Buddhist philosophy.

4. Explore the relevant concepts and issues in their contemporary significance.
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Social and Political Philosophy
courses.description:
This course is an introduction to the key issues in social and political philosophy. Topics treated may include any of the following issues: the human nature; the origin and justification of the state; theories of rights, democracy, liberty, and distributive justice; the relation between ethics and politics.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Assess on their own how plausible each theory is.

2. Develop ideas of their own.

3. In their papers, students should reflect on their knowledge of various theories, as well as their own criticisms of them.

4. Develop own original views.

This course is an introduction to the key issues in social and political philosophy. Topics treated may include any of the following issues: the human nature; the origin and justification of the state; theories of rights, democracy, liberty, and distributive justice; the relation between ethics and politics.

本科旨在介紹社會與政治哲學中的主要理論，討論題目可包括：人性論；國家之起源及理據；倫理與政治之關係；權利、民主、自由之理論；以及分配的公正等問題。
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be a fair way to estimate how the course was received by the students. The course instructor should also assess the various ways in which the course was taught.

2. Robert Nozick, Anarchy, State and Utopia.

3. Michael Walzer, Spheres of Justice.

4. H. L. A. Hart, Law, Liberty and Morality.

5. J. S. Mill, On Liberty.

6. Patrick Devlin, The Enforcement of Morals.

7. Thomas Hobbes, Leviathan.

8. Locke, Second Treatise on Government.

9. Rousseau, Social Contract.

10. Kant, Metaphysical Elements of Justice.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Practical Ethics
courses.description:
This course examines a range of moral problems confronting individuals in today’s society, showing how philosophical thought can be brought to bear upon contemporary issues. Among the topics that may be discussed are theories of normative ethics, abortion, euthanasia, criminal punishment and the death penalty, the enforcement of morals, obligations to help poor nations, censorship, animal rights, deep ecology, and environmental issues.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2841
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the characteristics and value of ethical theories.

2. Understand the characteristics and importance of some controversial and difficult ethical-social issues.

3. Ability to apply normative ethics to the issues and form considered judgments concerning them.

4. Ability to explain and assess different moral stances in a perspicuous, non-doctrinaire way.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophical Problems and Computational Tools
courses.description:
In this digital age, philosophical inquiries can benefit from embracing powerful computational tools in their methodology. This course is an introduction to the use of computational tools in the investigation of philosophical problems and will focus on some prominent examples of leveraging computation tools in addressing philosophically significant issues. These examples may include (but are not limited to)
• tools for data analysis in general (such as JASP) and corpus analysis in particular (such as Voyant), in connection with inquiries in the history of philosophy and in experimental philosophy
• tools for agent-based modelling (such as NetLogo), in connection with inquiries in social epistemology and in moral and political philosophy
• tools for probabilistic and causal modelling (such as Tetrad), in connection with inquiries in Bayesian epistemology and in general philosophy of science
• tools for virtual reality (such as A-Frame), in connection with inquiries in traditional metaphysics and epistemology.
Specific tools to be introduced in this course and related philosophical topics to be discussed are likely to vary from semester to semester, but the core purpose of the course remains the same: to expose students to various ways computational tools can help with philosophical investigations and to give them hands-on experience in using the tools to address philosophically motivated problems. In addition to exploring the power of computational methods, this course will also help students understand their limitations.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Identify and explain various ways philosophical inquiries can be enhanced by computational methods.

2. Grasp and reproduce a prominent example of using computational tools in philosophical research.

3. Demonstrate proficiency in using selected computational tools.

4. Develop the ability to design and carry out a small-scale project with the aid of computational tools.

5. Develop critical reflection about the benefits and limitations of computational methods.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is about the use of computational tools in the investigation of philosophical problems and will survey selected examples of leveraging computation tools in addressing philosophically significant issues. Specific examples may differ from semester to semester and instructor to instructor, but core areas will include:
1. tools for data/text analysis, in connection with history of philosophy and/or experimental philosophy
2. tools for agent-based modelling, in connection social epistemology and moral philosophy
3. tools for probabilistic and causal modelling, in connection with inquiries in Bayesian epistemology and general philosophy of science

In addition, virtual reality and related tools are another likely though optional topic, as well as the use of generative AI and specifically large language models.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Analytic Philosophy
courses.description:
This course scrutinizes some of the most influential ideas in analytic philosophy, focusing on topics in logic, the philosophy of language, and metaphysics. Topics to be discussed may include: (1) The New Logic (Frege); (2) Logical Atomism (Russell); (3) Verificationism (Vienna Circle); (4) Ordinary Language (Wittgenstein); and (5) Ontological Commitments (Quine).

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the characteristics and importance of philosophical theories in the analytic tradition.

2. Ability to use the philosophical method of conceptual analysis.

3. Ability to evaluate the most important achievements emerging from the analytic tradition.

4. Understand the philosophical significance of modern logic.

5. Understand the philosophical significance of the philosophy of language.
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Aesthetics
courses.description:
This course is a critical introduction to the main problems and theories in aesthetics. The themes discussed will include the meaning of beauty; aesthetic attitude; aesthetic experience; the variety of arts; the essence of art; the creation, interpretation, evaluation, and function of works of art.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the emergence of aesthetic theories.

2. Grasp the contribution of aesthetic to the understanding of the human condition.

3. Develop a critical view on aesthetic theories themselves.

4. Grasp the potential of aesthetic theories in promoting intercultural understanding.

5. Develop students’ ability to research independently on the issues taught.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Comparative Philosophy of Religion
courses.description:
This course introduces philosophy of religion with a global perspective and a comparative approach. It will explore the reasons and rationalities embedded in a variety of religious traditions including Buddhism, Chinese religions (Confucianism and Daoism), Christianity, Hinduism, Islam and Judaism. The main topics will fall into three areas: the human condition, ultimate realities, and religious truth.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge of major world religions in a comparative approach.

2. Understand the major concepts and issues in philosophy of religion.

3. Ability to work independently and critically on related primary and secondary sources.

4. Explore the contemporary relevance of concepts and issues discussed.

The main topics will fall into three areas: the human condition, ultimate realities, and religious truth.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Legal Philosophy
courses.description:
This course examines normative and analytical topics concerning law. Normative topics may include: The Hart-Devlin debate: Should the morality of the majority be enforced by the law? What is the justification of criminal punishment? Should capital punishment be implemented? As regards analytical topics, we may study what the concept of law is. This may include the Hart-Dworkin debate, and the Hart-Fuller debate. We may also study the views of Marx, and the Critical Legal Studies Movement. (Emphasis of the course may be different from year to year.)

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2861
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Assess on their own how plausible each theory is.

2. Develop ideas of their own.

3. In their papers, students should reflect their knowledge of various theories, as well as their own criticisms of them. They are also encouraged to put forward their own original views.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course examines normative and analytical topics concerning law. Normative topics may include: The Hart-Devlin debate: Should the morality of the majority be enforced by the law? What is the justification of criminal punishment? Should capital punishment be implemented? As regards analytical topics, we may study what the concept of law is. This may include the Hart-Dworkin debate, and the Hart-Fuller debate. We may also study the views of Marx, and the Critical Legal Studies Movement. (Emphasis of the course may be different from year to year.)

本科討論有關法律的規範性及分析性問題。規範性的問題可包括：法律應否推行大多數人的道德？刑罰的根據是什麼? 應否執行死刑？分析性課題所討論的問題可包括：法律的概念是什麼、赫特和德沃金的爭論、赫特和傅勒的爭論，以及馬克思與批判法律學派的見解。（本科的重點可能每年不同。）
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation should be relied on as an estimate as to how the course was received by the students. The course instructor should also assess the various ways in which the course was taught..

courses.recommended_readings:
1. John Austin, The Province of Jurisprudence Determined.

2. H. L. A Hart, The Concept of Law.

3. H. L. A. Hart, Law, Liberty and Morality.

4. J. S. Mill, On Liberty.

5. Patrick Devlin, The Enforcement of Morals.

6. Antony Duff and David Garland, eds., A Reader on Punishment.

7. Ronald Dworkin, Taking Rights Seriously.

8. Ronald Dworkin, The Law’s Empire.

9. Lon Fuller, The Morality of Law.

10. Maureen Cain & Alan Hunt, eds., Marx and Engels on Law.

11. G. A. Cohen, Karl Marx’s Theory of History: A Defence.

12. Roberto Unger, The Critical Legal Studies Movement.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Love
courses.description:
This course discusses the idea of love in the Western philosophical tradition, from Plato’s eros, Aristotle’s philia, the Christian agape, through the idea of passionate love in the Middle Ages, to the phenomenology of love in the 20th century. The problem of love, i.e. qing, in the Chinese philosophical tradition will also be discussed.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken GDRS2003 or UGED2891
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Ability to understand the complex meaning of the concept of love in Western and Chinese philosophical traditions.

2. Ability to read the classic texts on love.

3. Ability to reflect critically on the phenomenon of love.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course discusses the idea of love in the Western philosophical tradition, from Plato’s eros, Aristotle’s philia, the Christian agape, through the idea of passionate love in the Middle Ages, to the phenomenology of love in the 20th century. The problem of love, i.e. qing, in the Chinese philosophical tradition will also be discussed.

本科旨在探討西方哲學傳統中論愛情之問題。柏拉圖之「欲愛」、亞里士多德之「德愛」、基督教之「博愛」、中世紀之激情愛，以至近代愛情現象學等皆為本科之論題。同時亦探討中國傳統中「情」之哲學意義。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Death
courses.description:
This course examines the philosophy of death in the Western and Chinese cultural traditions. Major topics include: the classical philosophy of death of Plato, Epicurus, and the Stoics; the argument of immortality in Christian philosophy, Descartes, and Kant; the phenomenological analysis of death by Heidegger, Lévinas, and Derrida; and Chinese thought on death in Confucianism and Daoism.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED2901
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Ability to understand the meaning of death in both Western and Chinese philosophical traditions.

2. Ability to read and understand the classic text on philosophy of death.

3. Ability to understand the existential relevance of philosophy of death to everyday life.

4. Ability to reflect on the meaning of life in contrast to death.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course examines the philosophy of death in the Western and Chinese cultural traditions. Major topics include: the classical philosophy of death of Plato, Epicurus, and the Stoics; the argument of immortality in Christian philosophy, Descartes, and Kant; the phenomenological analysis of death by Heidegger, Lévinas, and Derrida; and Chinese thought on death in Confucianism and Daoism.

本科旨在探討中西文化傳統對死亡之哲學反省，主要課題包括：柏拉圖、伊壁鳩魯及斯多亞學派之死亡哲學；基督教哲學、笛卡兒及康德對不朽之討論；海德格、萊維納斯及德里達對死亡之現象學分析；以及儒家和道家之死亡思想。

5. The Routledge History of Philosophy, V. 7, The Nineteenth Century, ed. C.L. Ten, London ; New York : Routledge, 1994.

6. The Routledge History of Philosophy, V. 9, Philosophy of Science, Logic and Mathematics in the Twentieth Century, ed. Stuart G. Shanker, London ; New York : Routledge, 1996.

7. The Routledge History of Philosophy, V. 10, Philosophy of Meaning, Knowledge and Value in the Twentieth Century, ed. John V. Canfield, London ; New York : Routledge, 1997.

8. The Cambridge History of Philosophy, 1870-1945, ed. Thomas Baldwin, New York : Cambridge University Press, 2003.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Metaphysics
courses.description:
This course discusses some central problems in metaphysics and reflects on the nature of metaphysics. Topics include: the foundation of metaphysical questioning in Parmenides, Being and appearance in Plato, Being and becoming in Aristotle, Descartes and the metaphysics of subjectivity, Hume’s challenge to metaphysical inquiry, Kant and the recommencement of metaphysics, metaphysics and the quest for absolute knowledge in Hegel, personal identity, the mind-body problem, free will, and causation.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the connection between metaphysical issues and other philosophical issues.

2. Grasp major themes in metaphysics.

3. Understand the relevance of metaphysical issues to/for the contemporary human setting.

4. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course discusses some central problems in metaphysics and reflects on the nature of metaphysics. Topics include: the foundation of metaphysical questioning in Parmenides, Being and appearance in Plato, Being and becoming in Aristotle, Descartes and the metaphysics of subjectivity, Hume’s challenge to metaphysical inquiry, Kant and the recommencement of metaphysics, metaphysics and the quest for absolute knowledge in Hegel, personal identity, the mind-body problem, free will, and causation.

本科旨在探討形上學的一些重要問題提，並藉此反省形上學的本質。處理的問題包括：巴門尼德斯與形上學發問的奠基性開端、柏拉圖存在與表象的對揚、亞里士多德存在與變化的探究、笛卡兒與主體性形上學、休謨對形上學的挑戰、康德與形上學的再出發、黑格爾與形上學作為絕對知識的追索、個人的同一、心靈與肉體、自由意志及因果關係等 。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Bioethics
courses.description:
Bioethics can be defined as the study of ethical issues broadly relating to the lives and well-being of both humans and non-human animals, issues that often arise as a result of advances in medical technology. This course will offer an introduction to the field of bioethics. We will begin by examining the relationship between bioethics and ethical theories like consequentialism or deontology, and discussing the challenge from ethical relativism to the validity of the normative conclusions defended by bioethicists. With that theoretical basis in place, we will then proceed to discuss some central issues in bioethics, from the ethics of abortion to the genetic selection of future children, via a close reading of influential texts in the field.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Gain familiarity with the major issues and prominent positions in contemporary bioethics.

2. Understand the key concepts used in philosophical discussions of those issues.

3. Critically discuss and evaluate the main arguments and positions on the issues discussed in the course.

4. Demonstrate the ability to clearly articulate one’s own arguments and views on bioethical issues, both in oral discussion and in writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
Bioethics can be defined as the study of ethical issues broadly relating to the lives and well-being of both humans and non-human animals, issues that often arise as a result of advances in medical technology. This course will offer an introduction to the field of bioethics. We will begin by examining the relationship between bioethics and ethical theories like consequentialism or deontology, and discussing the challenge from ethical relativism to the validity of the normative conclusions defended by bioethicists. With that theoretical basis in place, we will then proceed to discuss some central issues in bioethics, from the ethics of abortion to the genetic selection of future children, via a close reading of influential texts in the field.

生物倫理學，主要研究關乎人類和其他生物的生命及福祉的道德議題，而這些議題通常由醫療科技的發展而引起。
本課旨在介紹生物倫理學，首先檢視學科與其他倫理學理論（如效果論、義務論）的關係；然後討論由道德相對主義、生物倫理學家捍衛的規範性結論的有效性所帶來的挑戰。奠定一定的理論基礎後，本課將深入研讀生物倫理學的重要著作，從而探討墮胎、為胎兒進行基因選擇等等核心議題。
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Feedback from lecture and tutorial discussions.

Teaching evaluation.

Teacher’s reflections.
courses.required_readings:
Most of the readings for this course will be drawn from the following two edited volumes:

LaFollette, Hugh (ed.). Ethics in Practice: An Anthology, 4th edition, Malden, Mass.: Wiley-Blackwell, 2013 (henceforth abbreviated “Ethics in Practice”).

Cohen, Andrew I. & Wellman, Christopher Heath (eds.). Contemporary Debates in Applied Ethics, 2nd edition, Malden, Mass.: Wiley-Blackwell, 2013 (henceforth abbreviated “Contemporary Debates”).

Both books are available online via the CUHK library catalogue (LibrarySearch).
courses.recommended_readings:
Other useful resources that can be consulted on this topic include:

Steinbock, Bonnie (ed.). The Oxford Handbook of Bioethics, Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2007.

Kuhse, Helga & Singer, Peter (eds.). Bioethics. An Anthology, 3rd edition, Oxford: Wiley-Blackwell, 2015.

Reading list :

Baker, “A Theory of International Bioethics: Multiculturalism, Postmodernism, and the Bankruptcy of Moral Fundamentalism”. Kennedy Institute of Ethics Journal 8:3 (1998), pp. 201-31.

Callahan, Daniel. “A Case Against Euthanasia”. In Contemporary Debates, pp. 82-92.

Cohen, Carl. “The Case for the Use of Animals in Biomedical Research”. In Ethics in Practice, pp. 198-203.

Gordon, John-Stewart. “Bioethics”. Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Available online: URL = http://www.iep.utm.edu/bioethic/#SH5d [accessed 18/10/2017].

Harris, John. “’Goodbye Dolly?’ The Ethics of Human Cloning”. In Ethics in Practice, pp. 265-73.

Kass, Leon R. “The Wisdom of Repugnance: Why We Should Ban the Cloning of Humans”. In Ethics in Practice, pp. 274-82.

LaFollette, Hugh. “Why Cohen Is Mistaken”. In Ethics in Practice, pp. 204-14.

Macklin, Ruth. “A Defense of Fundamental Principles and Human Rights: A Reply to Robert Baker”. Kennedy Institute of Ethics Journal 8:4 (1998), pp. 404-22.

Marquis, Don. “An Argument that Abortion is Wrong”. In Ethics in Practice, pp. 141-50.

Regan, Tom. “Empty Cages: Animal Rights and Vivisection”. In Contemporary Debates, pp. 95-108.

Savulescu, Julian & Kahane, Guy. “The Moral Obligation to Create Children with the Best Chance of the Best Life”. Bioethics 23:5 (2009), pp. 274-90.

Sparrow, Robert. “A Not-So-New Eugenics: Harris and Savulescu on Human Enhancement”. Hastings Center Report 41:1 (2011), pp. 32-42.

Thomson, Judith Jarvis. “A Defense of Abortion”. In Ethics in Practice, pp. 124-31.

Tooley, Michael. “In Defense of Voluntary Active Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide”. In Contemporary Debates, pp. 65-81.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Chinese Buddhist Philosophy
courses.description:
This course provides a critical survey of the basic problems of various schools of Chinese Buddhism (including Sanlun-Madhyamaka, Tiantai, Faxiang-Yogācāra, and Huayan) based on a close study of their writings. It also explores the characteristics of Chinese Buddhism through a comparative study with Indian Buddhism.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge regarding five major philosophical schools of Chinese Buddhism.

2. Understand the central issues of Chinese Buddhist philosophy in three major areas, i.e., metaphysics, ethics, and philosophy of religion.

3. Ability to work independently and critically on the primary and secondary sources in Chinse Buddhist philosophy;
4. Explore the relevant concepts and issues in their contemporary significance.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course provides a critical survey of the basic problems of various schools of Chinese Buddhism (including Sanlun-Madhyamaka, Tiantai, Faxiang-Yogācāra, and Huayan) based on a close study of their writings. It also explores the characteristics of Chinese Buddhism through a comparative study with Indian Buddhism.

本科以「問題」為中心，解析中國佛學各派（包括三論、天台、法相唯識、華嚴）之代表性著作，並通過與印度佛學之比較研究，說明中國佛學之特色及精神所在。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Chan Buddhism
courses.description:
This course introduces Chan Buddhism from historical, philosophical, and textual approaches. With respect to historical developments, it will examine the transition of this tradition from India to China. With regard to philosophical and doctrinal aspects, it will explore the characteristics of Chinese Chan through a comparative study with Indian, Tibetan, and Japanese Buddhist traditions. Besides lectures, seminars will be arranged to read and discuss selected core texts.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire knowledge of Chan Buddhism against the general background of Indian, Chinese, Tibetan and Japanese Buddhism.

2. Understand the perplexity of the central issues in Chan Buddhism that challenges our usual ways of approaching philosophy.

3. Ability to work independently and critically on the primary and secondary sources in Chan Buddhism.

4. Explore the relevant concepts and issues in their contemporary significance.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces Chan Buddhism from historical, philosophical, and textual approaches. With respect to historical developments, it will examine the transition of this tradition from India to China. With regard to philosophical and doctrinal aspects, it will explore the characteristics of Chinese Chan through a comparative study with Indian, Tibetan, and Japanese Buddhist traditions. Besides lectures, seminars will be arranged to read and discuss selected core texts.

本科主要從歷史發展、哲學教義及文獻研讀三方面，來探討禪宗哲學的基本學說。此即從歷史發展看，了解襌學由印度傳至中國的過程中產生的變化；從哲學教義看，對比中國禪學與印度佛教、藏傳佛教和日本佛教，以求揭示其特色；並且在講解之外，研讀有關文獻。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Song Neo-Confucian Philosophy
courses.description:
The course investigates the philosophical thoughts and their development of Song Neo-Confucianism, through intensive reading and interpretation of the basic writings of its towering figures such as Zhou Dunyi, Zhang Zai, the Cheng brothers, Zhu Xi, Lu Jiuyuan.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand Song Neo-Confucianism.

2. Acquire skills in textual study, philosophical thinking and writing.

3. Reflect the modern relevance of Song Neo-Confucian philosophy.

4. Be able to engage in critical discussion, to put forward and defend their own ideas concerning Song Neo-Confucian philosophy.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Culture
courses.description:
This course provides an introduction to philosophy of culture. Topics include: the distinction between culture and nature; the differences between cultural and natural sciences in terms of goal and method. Emphasis will be put on the diversity of methodological approaches. Comparative study of different cultural fields and their philosophical bearings will also be treated.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the emergence of various theories in philosophy of culture.

2. Grasp the contribution of philosophical reflections of culture to the understanding of the human condition.

3. Develop critical view on theories in philosophy of culture themselves.

4. Grasp the potential of philosophy of culture in reflections on intercultural understanding.

5. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course provides an introduction to philosophy of culture. Topics include: the distinction between culture and nature; the differences between cultural and natural sciences in terms of goal and method. Emphasis will be put on the diversity of methodological approaches. Comparative study of different cultural fields and their philosophical bearings will also be treated.

本科旨在從哲學反省的角度審視文化。內容包括：文化與自然的區分；文化科學與自然科學在研究方法與旨趣上的差異等。本科亦著重探討文化哲學在研究方法上的多樣性，及不同文化領域的比較研究與其哲學意涵。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Science
courses.description:
The course will provide an overview of classical debates, standard topics, and some recent developments in the philosophy of science, such as the structure of scientific theories, explanation, induction and probability, reduction, space and time, and the interpretation of quantum theories.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Identify and articulate a wide range of problems and issues in philosophy of science.

2. Demonstrate a solid grasp of central concepts in the subject, such as explanation, natural law, and causation.

3. Articulate the main features of the methodology of modern science.

4. Articulate the main features of scientific theories.

5. Understand how theories from different scientific disciplines are related.
courses.course_syllabus: This course discusses problems concerning the justification of induction, space and time, life and mind, principle of causality, the Uncertainty Principle, theory of paradigm, methodological pluralism, etc.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Kant
courses.description:
This course aims at a detailed study of the philosophy of Kant. Course material will be taken from the major texts of Kant such as Critique of Pure Reason, Critique of Practical Reason, Critique of the Power of Judgment, and Religion within the Boundaries of Mere Reason.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate familiarity with the main ideas in Kant's philosophy.

2. In their papers, students should also demonstrate the ability to understand the works of Kant, to identify a significant problem in his philosophy and formulate and defend a thesis of their own concerning the problem.
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: German Idealism
courses.description:
This course deals with the German philosophical development after Kant. Topics may include: Fichte’s science of knowledge, Schelling’s philosophy of nature, and Hegel’s logic and phenomenology of spirit.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate familiarity with the main ideas and theories of the German idealists.

2. In their papers, students should also demonstrate the ability to understand the works of the German idealists, to identify a significant problem in their philosophy and formulate and defend a thesis of their own concerning the problem.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Existentialism
courses.description:
This course examines the background and characteristics of the philosophies of existence, such as those of Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Jaspers, Heidegger and Sartre.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the emergence of philosophies of existence.

2. Grasp the concepts and philosophical issues discussed by existential philosophers.

3. Acquire a critical view on the doctrines put forward by philosophers of existence.

4. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:

courses.description:
This course is a general introduction to phenomenology and the phenomenological movement. The method, basic concepts and issues of Husserl’s phenomenology of the consciousness and Heidegger’s phenomenology of Dasein will be discussed. The existential phenomenology of Sartre will also be introduced.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the birth of the phenomenological movement.

2. Understand phenomenology’s innovation in terms of the idea and method of philosophy within the Western philosophical tradition.

3. Grasp the contribution of phenomenology in the understanding of the human condition.

4. Develop critical view on the phenomenological movement itself.

5. Grasp the potential of phenomenology in promoting intercultural understanding.

6. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is a general introduction to phenomenology and the phenomenological movement. The method, basic concepts and issues of Husserl’s phenomenology of the consciousness and Heidegger’s phenomenology of Dasein will be discussed. The existential phenomenology of Sartre will also be introduced.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Hermeneutics
courses.description:
This course examines the major problems and issues of hermeneutics and their development. Topics studied may include: the hermeneutic question of Schleiermacher and Dilthey; the contribution of Heidegger’s fundamental ontology to hermeneutics; Gadamer’s establishment of philosophical hermeneutics; Ricoeur’s development of hermeneutics.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the conditions giving raise to hermeneutics as a philosophical discipline and its development in the 20th century.

2. Grasp the basic concepts and philosophical issues discussed by various hermeneutical philosophers.

3. Acquire a critical view on the doctrines put forward by hermeneutical philosophers.

4. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course examines the major problems and issues of hermeneutics and their development. Topics studied may include: the hermeneutic question of Schleiermacher and Dilthey; the contribution of Heidegger’s fundamental ontology to hermeneutics; Gadamer’s establishment of philosophical hermeneutics; Ricoeur’s development of hermeneutics.

The course discusses major issues, theories, and figures in contemporary Anglo-American philosophy. Topics may include: philosophy of language, epistemology, mind and consciousness, ethics, moral psychology, and political philosophy.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:

2. In their papers, students should also demonstrate the ability to identify a significant philosophical problem and formulate and defend a thesis of their own concerning it.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Critical Theory
courses.description:
The course examines the main ideas of the critical theory propounded by the founding thinkers of the Frankfurt School (Horkheimer, Adorno, Marcuse), their historical antecedents (Kant and Marx), their followers (Habermas and Honeth) as well as their contemporary contenders (such as Foucault and Lyotard). Issues to be discussed include: the Enlightenment, the concept of instrumental reason, the culture industry, the predicament of modernity, the fate of historical materialism, the theory of communicative rationality, the critique of power, the relation with postmodernist theory.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the emergence of Critical Theory.

2. Grasp the contribution of Critical Theory to the understanding of the human condition

3. Develop critical view on theories propounded by Critical Theorists.

4. Grasp the relevance of Critical Theory to non-Western cultures.

5. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course examines the main ideas of the critical theory propounded by the founding thinkers of the Frankfurt School (Horkheimer, Adorno, Marcuse), their historical antecedents (Kant and Marx), their followers (Habermas and Honeth) as well as their contemporary contenders (such as Foucault and Lyotard). Issues to be discussed include: the Enlightenment, the concept of instrumental reason, the culture industry, the predicament of modernity, the fate of historical materialism, the theory of communicative rationality, the critique of power, the relation with postmodernist theory.

本科將探討法蘭克福學派的學說，研讀的思想家包括其歷史的先驅者（康德、馬克思）、理論的奠基者（賀爾克海姆、亞當諾、馬庫塞）、後起的理論家（哈貝馬斯、漢內特）及理論的挑戰者（傅柯、李歐塔）等，討論的問題包括：啟蒙運動、工具理性的概念、文化工業、現代的困境、歷史唯物論的命運、溝通理性論、對權力的批判、與後現代論說的關係等。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Language
courses.description:
This course investigates the basic concepts and working principles in the philosophy of language. It includes, among other topics, theory of definition, articulation and meaning, synonymity and translatability, analyticity and syntheticity, language and truth, and language and reality. Depending on the teacher offering the course, emphasis and readings may differ slightly from year to year. Philosophers covered might include: Plato, Aristotle, Locke, Leibniz, Wilhelm von Humboldt, Saussure, Wittgenstein, Chomsky, Quine, Jakobson, Davidson, Lakoff.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes: Through class presentation, group discussion, writing assignments, book reports and/or final paper, students will be expected to demonstrate familiarity with the major ideas and theories of the philosophers of language, as well as the relations between linguistic theories and linguistic realities.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course investigates the basic concepts and working principles in the philosophy of language. It includes, among other topics, theory of definition, articulation and meaning, synonymity and translatability, analyticity and syntheticity, language and truth, and language and reality. Depending on the teacher offering the course, emphasis and readings may differ slightly from year to year. Philosophers covered might include: Plato, Aristotle, Locke, Leibniz, Wilhelm von Humboldt, Saussure, Wittgenstein, Chomsky, Quine, Jakobson, Davidson, Lakoff.

本科主要目的在於探討語言哲學之基本概念及運用原則，講解內容包括界說論、分節論及意義論、同義性與可翻譯性、分析性與綜合性、語言與真理，及語言與現實等。尤其注重最近語言分析之發展對於解決各類哲學問題的貢獻和啟發。視乎開課老師的選題，科目重點及文獻取材在不同年度可能有不同偏重。本科會論及的哲學家可包括柏拉圖、亞里斯多德、洛克、萊布尼茲、洪堡特、索緒爾、維根斯坦、喬姆斯基、奎恩、雅各布遜、戴維森、賴可夫等。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of History
courses.description:
This course introduces philosophical reflections on history. It investigates on the one hand problems around the mode of constitution and the specificity of historical knowledge, such as the objectivity of historical knowledge, the concept of causation in history, the nature of historical explanation, historical time and historical memory. On the other hand it treats the problem of the meaning of human history and the related issue of cultural-centrism. Views from the philosopher and the professional historian will both be considered.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the emergence of various schools of philosophy of history.

2. Access the contribution of philosophical reflections of history to the understanding of the human condition.

3. Acquire a critical view on theories proposed by various philosophers of history.

4. Access the contribution of philosophies of history to reflections on intercultural understanding.

5. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course introduces philosophical reflections on history. It investigates on the one hand problems around the mode of constitution and the specificity of historical knowledge, such as the objectivity of historical knowledge, the concept of causation in history, the nature of historical explanation, historical time and historical memory. On the other hand it treats the problem of the meaning of human history and the related issue of cultural-centrism. Views from the philosopher and the professional historian will both be considered.

本科旨在從事對歷史的哲學反省，一方面探討歷史知識的構成及其獨特性，如歷史知識的客觀性、歷史中的因果概念、歷史說明、歷史時間及歷史記憶的性質等問題；另一方面探討人類歷史是否有意義及其相關的文化中心論問題。歷史哲學家及專業歷史學家的考察和反省均會探討。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Mind
courses.description:
This course investigates the principal issues and theories in contemporary philosophy of mind. Topics addressed may include the mind-body problem, consciousness, self-knowledge, knowledge of other minds, personal identity, and artificial intelligence.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate familiarity with a range of problems, concepts, and theories in contemporary philosophy of mind pertaining to topics such as the mind-body problem, consciousness, self-knowledge, knowledge of other minds, personal identity, and artificial intelligence.

2. In their papers, students should also demonstrate the ability to identify a significant problem in the philosophy of mind and formulate and defend a thesis of their own concerning the problem.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course investigates the principal issues and theories in contemporary philosophy of mind. Topics addressed may include the mind-body problem, consciousness, self-knowledge, knowledge of other minds, personal identity, and artificial intelligence.

本科探討有關心靈之主要問題及理論，包括心身問題、意識、自我知識、我外心靈、人身同一性與人工智能。

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Philosophy of Education
courses.description:
This course will analyze the basic concepts of education and examine both the Chinese and Western educational thoughts in order to help students to reflect on and understand the basic philosophical problems involved. This course will broaden students’ perspective and strengthen their ability in educational practice and research.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Grasp the basic concepts of education.

2. Understand how philosophical presuppositions influence the aim, content, policy and method of education.

3. Acquire general knowledge and understand major Chinese and Western educational thoughts.

4. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will analyze the basic concepts of education and examine both the Chinese and Western educational thoughts in order to help students to reflect on and understand the basic philosophical problems involved. This course will broaden students’ perspective and strengthen their ability in educational practice and research.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Mohist Philosophy
courses.description:
The course studies the philosophy of Mozi and his followers, its principal ideas and theoretical development, and its place in the history of Chinese philosophy.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the key concepts of and the philosophical issues raised by Mohist philosophy.

2. Demonstrate familiarity with the primary source and secondary sources.

3. Be able to articulate and defend a philosophical thesis of their own concerning Mohist philosophy.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course studies the philosophy of Mozi and his followers, its principal ideas and theoretical development, and its place in the history of Chinese philosophy.

courses.recommended_readings:
I 中文

9. 朱熹著，張京華注譯：《新譯近思錄》，香港：海嘯出版事業有限公司，2005

10. 王充著、袁華忠、方家常譯注：《論衡全譯》，貴陽市：貴州人民出版社，1993

11. 梁漱溟：《人心與人生》，香港：三聯書店(香港)有限公司，1985

12. 金觀濤：《人的哲學：論[科學與理性]的基礎》，香港：商務印書館，1988

13. 休謨著，關文運譯，鄭之驤校：《人性論》，北京：商務印書館，1980

14. 胡瀟：《意識的起源與結構》，北京：中國社會科學出版社，2004

15. 韓慶祥、鄒詩鵬著：《人學：人的問題的當代闡釋》，昆明：雲南人民出版社，2001

II 英文

1. Ernst Cassirer, An Essay on Man: An Introduction to a Philosophy of Human Culture, New York: Doubleday, 1944／恩斯特・凱西爾著，甘陽譯：《人論》，上海：上海譯文出版社, 1985

2. The Birth of Tragedy, and The Case of Wagner translated, with commentary, by Walter Kaufmann., New York: Vintage Books, 1967／周國平譯：《悲劇的誕生：尼采美學文選》，北京：生活.讀書.新知三聯書店，1986）

3. Friedrich Nietzsche, Thus Spake Zarathustra, translated by Thomas Common; revised, with an introduction and notes, by H. James Birx, Buffalo, N.Y.: Prometheus Books, 1993／王岳川編，周國平等譯：《尼采文集．查拉斯圖拉卷》，西寧市：靑海人民出版社，1995

4. Jean-Paul Sartre, Existentialism and Humanism, translation and introduction by Philip Mairet, S.l.: S.n., 1945

5. Merleau-Ponty, Phenomenology of Perception, translated from the French by Colin Smith, London: Routledge & K. Paul; New York : Humanities Press, 1962／莫里斯・梅洛龐蒂著，薑志輝譯：《知覺現象學》，北京：商務印書館，2001

6. Popper, Karl Raimund, Sir, The Open Society and its Enemies, Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1966／卡爾・巴柏著，莊文瑞，李英明聯合編譯，《開放社會及其敵人》

7. G. W. F. Hegel, Phenomenology of Spirit, translated by A. V. Miller, with analysis of the text and foreword by J. N. Findlay, Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1977／黑格爾著，賀麟、王玖興譯：《精神現象學》（第2版），北京：商務印書館，1979

3. Develop philosophical issues based on certain texts.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Contemporary French Philosophy
courses.description:
This course aims at providing a concise understanding of the basic characteristics and main achievements of the thinking of important contemporary French philosophers. Their contribution to the innovation of philosophical activity as well as their influence on other disciplines in the humanities and social sciences will also be discussed. The philosophers studied may be different from year to year, including: Merleau-Ponty, Lévinas, Ricoeur, Foucault, Derrida, Deleuze, Lyotard.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 2 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the historical and cultural conditions of the emergence of Contemporary French philosophy.

2. Understand Contemporary French philosophy’s innovation within the Western philosophical tradition.

3. Grasp the contribution of Contemporary French philosophy in the understanding of the human condition.

4. Develop critical view on Contemporary French philosophy itself.

5. Grasp the potential of Contemporary French philosophy in interdisciplinary research.

6. Enhanced ability to research independently on the issues taught.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course aims at providing a concise understanding of the basic characteristics and main achievements of the thinking of important contemporary French philosophers. Their contribution to the innovation of philosophical activity as well as their influence on other disciplines in the humanities and social sciences will also be discussed. The philosophers studied may be different from year to year, including: Merleau-Ponty, Lévinas, Ricoeur, Foucault, Derrida, Deleuze, Lyotard.

本科旨在介紹當代法國重要哲學家的基本思想特徵、主要成就、其於哲學活動帶來的創新及其對其他人文社會科學研究的影響。所研討的哲學家可隨年度更改，主要人物包括：梅洛龐蒂、李維納斯、利科、傅柯、德里達、德勒茲、李歐塔等。
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Teacher's observations of class discussion during lectures and tutorials

2. Out-of-class contact and discussions with students

3. Input from tutors

4. Course evaluation
courses.required_readings: To be specified by teacher from within the respective list of recommended readings.
courses.recommended_readings:
A. References on Contemporary French in general

1. Schrift, Alan D. Twentieth-Century French Philosophy. Key Themes and Thinkers (Malden, MA & Oxford, Blackwell Publishing, 2006), Part I, pp. 1-81.

2. Gutting, G. “Part I: The Philosophers of the Third Republic”, in French Philosophy in the Twentieth Century (Cambridge: Cambridge University Pr., 2001), pp. 1-117.

3. Matthews, Eric. “The Frenchness of French Philosophy”, Twentieth-Century French philosophy, Ch. 1 (Oxford & New York: Oxford University Press, 1996), pp. 1-13.

4. Descombes, V. “Introduction: Philosophy in France”, in Modern French Philosophy, Eng. trans. L. Scott-Fox & J.-M. Harding (Cambridge: Cambridge University Pr., 1980).

5. Spiegelberg, H. “The Beginnings of French Phenomenology”, in The Phenomenological Movement (The Hague: M. Nijhoff, 3rd revised & enlarged ed., 1980), Part 3, Chap. VIII, pp. 428-447；中譯本：《現象學運動》，赫伯特•施皮格伯格著，王炳文、張金言譯 (北京：商務印書館，1995)，頁593-619。

6. Dews, P. “Introduction”, Logic of Disintegration. Post-Structuralist Thought and the Claims of Critical Theory (London: Verso, 1987), pp. xi-xviii.

7. Chatelet, F. “Récit”, in M. Morris & P. Patton (ed.), Michel Foucault: Power, Truth, Strategy (Sydney: Feral Publications, 1979), pp. 13-28.

8. Williams, Caroline. “Inheriting Problems and Paradoxes: Subjectivity and Modern Philosophy”, in Contemporary French Philosophy. Modernity and the Persistence of the Subject, Ch. 1 (London & New York: The Athlone Press, 2001), pp. 12-37.

9. Lawlor, L. “Introduction: The Being of the Question”, in Thinking Through French Philosophy. The Being of the Question (Bloomington & Indianapolis: Indiana University Press, 2003), pp. 1-10.

10. 高宣揚：《當代法國思想五十年》，＜導論：關於人的命運與西方文化奧秘的思想論戰＞（台北：五南圖書，2003），頁1-160。

B. Basic texts of Merleau-Ponty, Foucault, Derrida and other French philosophers

1. Merleau-Ponty, Maurice, The Structure of Behavior, Eng. trans. A. L. Fisher (Boston: Beacon Pr., 1963)；《行為的結構》，梅洛－龐蒂著，楊大春、張堯均譯（北京：商務印書館，2005）。

2. The Phenomenology of Perception, Eng. trans. C. Smith (London: Routledge, 1962)；《知覺現象學》，梅洛－龐蒂著，姜志輝譯（北京：商務印書館，2001）。

3. The Primacy of Perception and other essays on Phenomenological Psychology, the Philosophy of Art, History and Politics, ed. & introd. James M. Edie (Evanston: Northwestern University Pr., 1964)；《知覺的首要地位及其哲學結論》，梅洛－龐蒂著，王東亮譯（北京：三聯，2002）。

4. Sense and non-sense, Eng. trans. Hubert L. Dreyfus and Patricia Allen Dreyfus (Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press, 1964).

5. In Praise of Philosophy and other Essays, Eng. Trans. John Wild and James Edie, John O”Neill ((Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press, 1988); 《哲學讚詞》，梅洛－龐蒂著，楊大春譯（北京：商務印書館，2002）。

6. Signs, Eng. trans. Richard C. McCleary (Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press, 1964); 《符號》， 梅洛－龐蒂著，姜志輝譯（北京：商務印書館，2003）。

7. The Visible and the Invisible, Eng. trans. A. Lingis (Evanston: Northwestern University Pr., 1968).

8. The World of Perception, Eng. Trans. Oliver Davis (London and New York: Routledge, 2004).

9. Maurice Merleau-Ponty: Basic Writings, ed. Thomas Baldwin (London & New York: Routledge, 2004).

10. Foucault, Michel. History of Madness, complete Eng. trans. Jonathan Murphy and Jean Khalfa (Abingdon, Oxon: Routledge, 2006)；傅柯：《古典時代瘋狂史》，林志明譯 (台北：時報文化，1998)；Madness and Civilization, partial Eng. trans. R. Howard (New York: Pantheon, 1965).

11. The Birth of the Clinic, Eng. trans. A. Sheridan (New York: Vintage, 1973)；《臨床醫學的誕生》，傅柯著 ，劉絮愷譯（台北市 : 時報文化，1995）。

12. The Order of Things, Eng. trans. A. Sheridan (New York: Random House, 1970)；《詞與物》，福柯著，莫偉民譯 (上海：上海三聯書店，2001)。

13. The Archaeology of Knowledge, Eng. trans. A. Sheridan (New York: Pantheon, 1972)；《知識考古學》，福柯著，謝強、馬月譯（ 北京：三聯，1998）。

14. Discipline and Punish: the Birth of the Prison, Eng. trans. Alan Sheridan (New York: Pantheon, 1977)；《規訓與懲罰 : 監獄的誕生》，傅柯著 ; 劉北成， 楊遠嬰譯（臺北市：桂冠圖書，1992）。

15. The history of sexuality, 3 Vols., Eng. trans. Robert Hurley (New York: Vintage Books, 1978-88)；《性經驗史》，福柯著，佘碧平譯（上海：上海人民出版社，2002）。

16. The Foucault Reader, ed. P. Rabinow (New York: Pantheon, 1985).

17. Ethics: Subjectivity and Truth, Essential Works of Foucault 1954-1984, Vol. 1, ed. P. Rabinow (New York: New Press, 1997).

18. Aesthetics, Method and Epistemology, Essential Works of Foucault 1954-1984, Vol. 2, ed. J. D. Faubion (New York: New Press, 1998).

19. Power, Essential Works of Foucault 1954-1984, Vol. 3, ed. James D. Faubion (New York: New Press, 2000).

20. 《福柯集》，杜小真編選 (上海：上海遠東出版社，1998)。

21. Derrida, Jacques, Speech and Phenomena and Other Essays on Husserl’s Theory of Signs, Eng. trans. D. Allison (Evanston: Northwestern University Pr., 1973)；《聲音與現象》，德里達著，杜小真譯（香港：社會理論出版社，1994；北京：商務，1999）。

22. Edmund Husserl’s Origin of Geometry: An Introduction, Eng. trans. J. Leavy (York Beach: ME, Nicholas Hays, 1978)；《胡塞爾＜幾何學的起源＞導引》，德希達著，錢捷譯（台北： 桂冠圖書，2005）。

23. Of Grammatology, Eng. trans. G. C. Spivak (Baltimore: Johns Hopskins University Pr., 1975)；《論文字學》，德里達著，汪堂家譯（上海：上海譯文出版社，1999）。

24. Writing and Difference, Eng. trans. A. Bass (Chicago: University of Chicago Pr., 1978)；《書寫與差異》，德里達著，張寧譯 (北京：三聯，2001)。

25. Margins of Philosophy, Eng. trans. A. Bass (Chicago: University of Chicago Pr., 1982).

26. A Derrida Reader: Between the Blinds, ed. P. Kamuf (New York: Columbia University Pr., 1991).

27. Acts of Religion, ed. G. Anidjar (New York and London: Routledge, 2002).

28. Negotiations: Interventions and Interviews, 1971-2001, ed. and Eng. trans. E. Rottenberg (Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2002)

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Seminar on Western Philosophy
courses.description:
This is a seminar course devoted to examining selected issues in Western philosophy. The specific content of the course varies from semester to semester. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

Advisory to Majors: to be taken in year 3 or above.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Gain competence in explaining and evaluating the key concepts and theories addressed in the course.

2. Demonstrate familiarity with the primary and secondary source texts in the syllabus.

3. Engage in in-depth discussion on the selected topics of the course.

4. Demonstrate ability to articulate and defend one’s own philosophical theses with clarity.

5. Demonstrate consolidated skills in expository and argument writing.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Seminar on Pre-modern Chinese Philosophy
courses.description: This course is designed to explore the major issues, movements, schools, or philosophers in pre-modern Chinese philosophy, such as classical Confucianism, Pre-Qin Daoism, Mohism, Legalists, Han Confucianism, Neo-Daoism of the Wei-Jin period, Song-Ming Neo-Confucianism, as well as hermeneutical issues in the interpretation of philosophical texts. The specific content of the course may vary from semester to semester. Students may repeat the course for credit, provided that two courses with identical course codes are not elected in the same semester.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil Philosophy or MA Philosophy
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate a solid grasp of the issues discussed.

2. Analyze and critically interpret some significant primary texts in Pre-modern Chinese philosophy.

3. Demonstrate an enhanced ability to conduct independent research on the topics covered and related issues.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is designed to explore major issues, movements, schools, and philosophers in pre-modern Chinese philosophical history, such as classical Confucianism, Pre-Ch'in Taoism, Mohism, Legalists, Han Confucianism, Hsuan-hsueh, Sung and Ming Confucianism, as well as hermeneutical issues in the interpretation of philosophical texts.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Seminar on Modern and Contemporary Chinese Philosophy
courses.description: The course is a postgraduate seminar devoted to investigating the philosophical thoughts in modern and contemporary China. Topics may include contemporary Neo-Confucianism, modern Daoist development, the conflicts and dialogues between the Chinese and Western philosophical traditions. The specific content of the course may vary from semester to semester. Students may repeat the course for credit, provided that two courses with identical course codes are not elected in the same semester.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil Philosophy or MA Philosophy
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate a solid grasp of the issues discussed.

2. Analyze and critically interpret some significant primary texts in modern and contemporary Chinese philosophy.

3. Demonstrate an enhanced ability to conduct independent research on the topics covered and related issues.
courses.course_syllabus: This course aims to investigate new forms of thought and philosophy in modern and contemporary China and their transformation from tradition to modernity. Topics may include Neo-Confucianism, modern Taoist developments, conflicts and confusion between Chinese tradition and Western philosophy, Communist ideology, and Marxism in China.

courses.subject: PHIL
courses.title: Seminar: Issues in the History of Chinese Philosophy
courses.description: This course aims to explore essential and methodological issues in the history of Chinese philosophy, including continuity and discontinuity in the development of Chinese philosophy; religiosity in Chinese philosophy; similarities and differences between Chinese and Western philosophy; possible directions and approaches for the development of Chinese philosophy in the contemporary world. The specific content of the course may vary from semester to semester. Students may repeat the course for credit, provided that two courses with identical course codes are not elected in the same semester.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil Philosophy or MA Philosophy
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Identify and articulate some major problems and issues in the history of Chinese Philosophy.
2. Demonstrate a solid grasp of the issues discussed.
3. Analyze and critically interpret some historical significant texts in Chinese philosophy.
4. Demonstrate an enhanced ability to conduct independent research on the topics covered and related issues.
courses.course_syllabus: This course aims to explore essential and methodological issues in the history of Chinese philosophy, including continuity and discontinuity in its development, religiosity in Chinese philosophy, similarities and differences between Chinese and Western philosophy, possible directions and approaches for development of Chinese philosophy in the contemporary world, evaluation of the application of Western philosophical concepts and methods in studies of Chinese philosophy, arguments about the authentic essence or authority of schools of Confucianism, research methodology, achievements and limitations of Western approaches to Chinese philosophy, and other concepts, problems, and debates in the history of Chinese philosophy.

The specific content of the course may vary from semester to semester and may cover such writers as Carnap, Davidson, Dennett, Dummett, Dworkin, Fodor, Kripke, MacIntyre, McDowell, Nagel, Nozick, Parfit, Putnam, Quine, Rawls, Rorty, Russell, Sellars, Taylor and Wittgenstein, among others. courses.description: This course is devoted to the study of a selected topic in the domain of Continental European philosophy, such as post-Hegelian philosophy, neo-Kantianism, phenomenology, philosophies of existence, hermeneutics, post-structuralism and critical theory. Continental European approaches to the study of philosophy of language, philosophy of history, and social and political philosophy, may also be themes of the seminar. The specific content of the course may vary from semester to semester. Students may repeat the course for credit, provided that two courses with identical course codes are not elected in the same semester.
